body: R: @dhalperi
PTAL @robertwb Thanks!
R: @kennknowles

TextIO.Read should works for all runners in streaming, as long as they support BoundedSource and UnboundedSource.

However, TextIO.Write still doesn't work in streaming with dataflow runner. And, it might also not work with other runners.

StreamingWordExtract is still useful for users to try run a pipeline in streaming mode. Once WordCount works in streaming mode, I agree that it will not longer useful as an example. But, I still see it can be useful as an integration test for new runners implementors.

R: @dhalperi @jasonkuster

Our current postprocessors don't support this (as far as I can tell; feel free to correct me). Checkstyle can't, as this is based on the class hierarchy, which it's unaware of. Findbugs doesn't have the ability either, as `@Override` is retained only on the source and it analyzes bytecode.

Error Prone is probably what we would want (plus plenty of other stuff), but that's a much more involved change.
http://errorprone.info/bugpattern/MissingOverride

I was just browsing the output and didn't even see what the error was. FWIW the travis errors are different but also seem unrelated. I've seen the Travis issue before but have forgotten what it was about.
LGTM. Just a couple of nits. I'll merge it regardless but I'm curious what you think of my little comments.

I haven't actually looked into this in detail before, so I thought I'd just relay what I dug up. Undoubtedly common knowledge to enthusiasts of language corner cases. It seems an extraneous `@Override` should be an error regardless (I didn't test this) while `-Xlint:overrides` adds some more subtle cases, but nothing seems to address the missing annotation.

Getting ErrorProne hooked up would be great. It might actually supersede findbugs. It does have a maven plugin: http://errorprone.info/docs/installation
Typo in the PR title comes from a typo in the commit subject line.

Hi Amit,

The logs are unfortunately a bit misleading, but there is one Javadoc error:

```
/home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/beam_PreCommit_MavenVerify/runners/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/
beam/runners/spark/examples/WordCount.java:38: error: reference not found
 * Duplicated from {@link org.apache.beam.examples.WordCount} to avoid dependency on
```

The link is not resolved because you removed the dependency on the examples module.

All the other Javadoc stuff is warnings and don't cause breaks.

Okay, I did a little more digging and here's my summary:
- Jenkins - legit Javadoc error.
- Travis - broken because the Travis part of the build was broken for a little bit.

A rebase should fix the latter.
LGTM, merging.
LGTM, merged.

To speed the review process, you can run `mvn verify` locally (or `mvn checkstyle:checkstyle` to just check CheckStyle) before pushing.

In any case, it's no problem for me to notice and point out issues ;). Thanks for the fix!

Thanks Kenn. Please note that these snippets are designed to be integrated into websites. There should be more details in text.

I can't :(. Not sure why the "Closes ..." comment didn't do the trick either.
Looks like there's no tests run under normal situation. How do we prevent bitrot?

The request was directed @silviulica.

As for why: @aaltay figured this out.

GitHub will _close_ the PR only when merged into `master`. You can mouse-over the question mark above to see this.

However, if the rebase onto `python-sdk` is a no-op, then the commit merged into `python-sdk` when you push will be the exact same commit (including hash) as the one in this PR. In that unique case, GitHub will mark this PR as _merged_.

R: @bjchambers
@kennknowles PTAL.
That's a great point about bitrot. It should suffice to run the benchmarks on a tiny amount of input to ensure that they build & don't crash.
R: @dhalperi added the v1beta3() redirect. "mvn verify" passes.
Great. Merging now.
PTAL

@wikier

Tox runs sdist prior to installing dependencies. sdist is done by setup.py to create a source distribution. There is a way to skip this step by adding 'skipsdist = True' under '[tox]'. However I am strongly against doing this because, this would mean that our users will require lxml package to be installed prior to creating a source distribution and later for installing and testing. I would rather avoid any dependencies that could not be managed by setup.py itself.

I am fine with a dirtier parsing approach. Just to clarify, I assume this will involve some simple string searches rather than a complex xml parsing.

On a separate note while I was trying to install lxml on one of my computers I got an error like this 'Could not find function xmlCheckVersion in library libxml2. Is libxml2 installed?' I think this it by itself a good reason to avoid this dependency. It is plausible that some of our users will end up seeing this error too.
OK, that's all for my first pass. Let me know if there is anything I can make easier.
Let me know if there is anything else I can make easier here. Happy to chat, etc.

This actually should probably be back in the SDK, since aggregators are a core aspect of a pipeline, but probably private to Pipeline.

I've added links. I plan to submit as is (since these benchmarks add value). The most likely bitrot is prevented by getting them in and compiling regularly. We should look at either (1) adding explicit unit tests for them -- a bit odd since benchmarks are already test-like or (2) including the benchmark runs in some nightly runs and putting them on a dashboard somewhere. I think (2) is the most preferable solution to preventing bitrot.

@ianzhou1 @dhalperi can you take a look?

Thanks for your pull request. 

The choice of 1e-7 here as a cutoff is arbitrary here; when choosing a bound for equality one needs to consider what makes sense in context, and there really isn't any context to go on here, thus I think the only correct thing to do here is leave exact equality. (Either that or simply remove the equals() method on CountSum, it's really not needed.)
OK @aaltay, I went for a dirtier parsing (regex-based) and now CI is happy (at least Travis, Jenkins fails because RAT).
